title: 3D Printed plate design
text:
Rather than woodworking, a 3D printed plate can be used as well. This design is based on a 3D-printed customizable fan grill cover. This thingiverse posted project contains OpenSCAD code to create a wide variety of fan covers. Several modifications have adapted it to a CR-box:

Increased the plate size to have overlap for fitting to MERV 13 filters but an extra border of 25 mm.
Removed rounded corners so that plates fit together more tightly.

These modifications can be found here.

title: References
text:
Dal Porto, Rachael, Monet N. Kunz, Theresa Pistochini, Richard L. Corsi, and Christopher D. Cappa. 2022. “Characterizing the Performance of a Do-It-Yourself (DIY) Box Fan Air Filter.” Aerosol Science and Technology 56 (6): 564–72. https://doi.org/10.1080/02786826.2022.2054674.


Srikrishna, Devabhaktuni. 2022. “Can 10× Cheaper, Lower-Efficiency Particulate Air Filters and Box Fans Complement High-Efficiency Particulate Air (HEPA) Purifiers to Help Control the COVID-19 Pandemic?” Science of The Total Environment 838 (September): 155884. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2022.155884.

title: DIY Corsi-Rosenthal Boxes
text:
The Corsi-Rosenthal Box is a DIY air-filter made from a box fan and MERV 13 air filters. This project is primarily a summary of references I’ve collected and information I’ve documented in the construction of my boxes.
This is the first box, built around December 2021 and rebuilt in September 2022 with new filters. Figure 2 shows the difference between a new and used filter.
This original box was largely used in an open basement. The box fan is a 20in. Hurricane which works well becuase the control is accessible, but it is louder than I’d like. The fitlers are 3M Filtrete 1900.







My original CR Box







Rebuilt CR box with new filters




Figure 1: CR filter after 8 months of use.





Figure 2: Comparison of New/Used filters


I built another box using a Honeywell Turbo Force 908 fan. This set up is much more quiet than the Hurricane box filter. This filter is also built with 20x20x2 and 20x15x2 MERV-13 filter instead of the 1in deep used previously.



Figure 3: Honeywell Turbo Force Filter

text:
Air flow

From technical specs each fan draws 72.8 CFM/ 123.8 m3/h

text:

At full power, draws 11-12 Watts.

This is the first box, built around December 2021 and rebuilt in September 2022 with new filters. Figure 2 shows the difference between a new and used filter.
This original box was largely used in an open basement. The box fan is a 20in. Hurricane which works well becuase the control is accessible, but it is louder than I’d like. The fitlers are 3M Filtrete 1900.







My original CR Box

Figure 2: Comparison of New/Used filters

title: CR Box based on Honeywell HT-908
text:
This is a version based on the Honeywell HT-908 fan. The version is more quiet than a box fan. The biggest drawback is that the fan control is not accessible in this design unless you cut an access panel in the box. The fan mounting was build with the box the fan came in. It’s mounted at an angle so that it doesn’t fall in, gaps are covered with duct tape.



CR Box built with Honeywell HT-908 fan
